fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Any natural transformation f _{*} \to g _{*} between the direct image part of the given geometric morphisms, f and g, corresponds to a unique natural transformation f ^{*} \to g ^{*} under the adjunctions f ^{*} \dashv f _{*} and g ^{*} \dashv g _{*}. Thus, a geometric transformation f \to g can be equivalently defined as a natural transformation f ^{*} \to g ^{*}.
Let \mathcal { E } and \mathcal { F } be topoi. A geometric morphism f \colon \mathcal { E } \to \mathcal { F } is an adjoint pair of functors
such that f ^{*} is left exact. The functors f _{*} and f ^{*} are called the direct image and the inverse image respectively.

Let f , g \colon \mathcal { E } \rightrightarrows \mathcal { F } be a pair of geometric morphisms. A geometric transformation \alpha \colon f \to g is a natural transformation \alpha \colon f _{*} \to g _{*}.
